news_header: Ratan Tata, the influential Indian tycoon and former chairman of Tata Group, has passed away at the age of 86.
news_text: Ratan Tata, aged 86, has died, as confirmed by the Tata Group, which he led for over two decades. Recognized as one of India's most prominent business leaders, Tata was instrumental in transforming the Tata Group into a global powerhouse, overseeing significant acquisitions like Corus, Jaguar, Land Rover, and Tetley. Current Tata Sons chairman Natarajan Chandrasekaran praised him as a 'truly uncommon leader', while Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi described him as a 'visionary business leader'. Born in 1937 and educated in architecture and structural engineering, Tata joined Tata Industries in 1962 and succeeded JRD Tata as chairman in 1991. He retired in 2012 but remained chairman emeritus. Tata was awarded the Padma Vibhushan in 2008 and was known for his modesty, love for fast cars, scuba diving, and dogs. His legacy continues to inspire many in the business world.
